case_vignette: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a painless skin lesion on his neck. The lesion has gradually become darker in color. Sometimes it is itchy. He also noticed one similar lesion on his lower back. He is a retired gardener. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 123/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule on his neck and a 0.6-cm hyperpigmented papule on his lower back, both of which have a greasy and wax-like appearance. A photograph of the neck is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on the information you've provided, it's possible that the darkening bump on your neck and the similar spot on your lower back could be related to a condition called melanoma. Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that can appear as a darkening or changing of the skin, often in the form of a mole or growth.

I would recommend that you schedule an appointment with a dermatologist as soon as possible to have your skin examined and to discuss your options for further testing and treatment. In the meantime, it's important to keep an eye on the spots and to monitor them for any changes in size, shape, or color.

Yes, that sounds like a good plan; I'll schedule an appointment with a dermatologist.

Great, that's good to know. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I would like to consider a few potential causes of the dark spots on your neck and lower back.

One possibility is that the spots could be a form of skin pigmentation, such as melasma or hyperpigmentation. This can occur when there is an increase in the production of melanin, the pigment that gives skin its color. This can be caused by a variety of factors, including hormonal changes, sun exposure, and certain medications.

Another possibility is that the spots could be a form of skin cancer, such as basal cell carcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma. These types of cancer are relatively common and can occur on any area of the body, including the skin. They are usually slow-growing and can be treated with surgery or other treatments.
